column4: One other question -- I'm going to convert my ext3 SSD and SD partitions to ext2 -- but what about the 'noatime' flag in fstab? Should I drop that?
why are you going to convert them to ext2?
b/c they're both flash-based media, and I can't have them die on me b/c of ext3's journaling
you are aware that if there is a power failure, it may corrupt the disk if you don't have journaling?
when you say corrupt -- recoverable (so I could format and reinstall)?
yeah, you can reinstall, but you'll lose the data obviously
then in my eyes -- better safe than sorry. And philpem makes a good point -- power failure is highly unlikely.
yeah, but if it crashes or something, same problem
although crashing/power failures are unlikely if you have a notebook
that's true -- my main concern is for the life of the flash media. I also read something about disabling swap. But doesn't that eliminate the ability to standby/hibernate?
you don't need swap for suspend but you will for hibernate
I don't own an SSD, but I've seen some calculations that indicate that you will never use up all the available writes
alright. So then perhaps I'm best off formatting the SD card as ext2 and leaving the SSD as ext3
I'd encourage you to look into the number of writes on SSDs if you're interested; like I said, I don't own one, so that may or may not be true
ext2 would probably be fine for the SD card
did you put part of ubuntu on the SD card?
yes. It's only a 2GB SSD, so I have most on the SSD and then /home and /usr on a 4GB SD card
